Award.AwardTitle: High Energy Gamma-Ray Astrophysics with VERITAS
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the last frontiers of high energy astrophysics is the exploration of the sky with TeV photons. Very high energy (VHE) gamma-ray measurements probe astrophysics involving extreme conditions of electromagnetic or gravitational potential and highly efficient particle acceleration. VHE gamma rays could also be signatures for new physics beyond the standard model of particle physics. This award provides funding for scientists at Barnard College to carry out particle astrophysics studies with VERITAS (Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System), located in southern Arizona. VERITAS is an array of four large imaging atmospheric Cherenkov telescopes that has been fully operational since spring 2007. It is the most sensitive gamma-ray telescope in the northern hemisphere and will complement the science from the four-telescope H.E.S.S. array in the southern hemisphere. The PI will focus on the study of extragalactic sources such as active galactic nuclei as well as Galactic unidentified TeV sources discovered by VERITAS. Blazars constitute one of the most extreme classes of active galaxies, distinguished by their high luminosity and rapid variability. Blazars, therefore, represent the ideal class for study to further our understanding of non-thermal emission in compact sources. In addition, the PI will carry out multiwavelength studies of unidentified TeV sources, crucial for resolving the nature of these objects.

The PI continues to play a strong role in outreach efforts to K-12 students. Activities have included student mentorships at local public schools, and public lectures. The PI's research at Barnard College, a 4-year liberal arts school for women, has significant impact in influencing women in the physical sciences, and the PI will continue to be a mentor to undergraduate women in astrophysics research. The education and outreach program for VERITAS is being led by the Adler Planetarium, and the PI will support these efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Very high energy (VHE) gamma-ray measurements probe astrophysics involving extreme conditions of electromagnetic or gravitational potential and highly efficient particle acceleration in the Universe. VHE gamma rays could also be signatures of new physics beyond the standard model of particle physics. The principal objective of the proposal was to carry out studies of VHE emission to understand particle acceleration and emission mechanisms in gamma-ray sources, focusing on studies of extragalactic sources such as active galactic nuclei as well as Galactic pulsar wind nebulae systems and unidentified TeV sources discovered by VERITAS.  VHE gamma-ray observations sample the sky at the highest photon energies, pointing towards nature's most extreme cosmic accelerators, and offer one of the most direct ways to study these sources. One such example, during the period of this award, was the discovery by VERITAS of TeV gamma-ray emission coincident with the shell-type radio supernova remnant (SNR) CTA 1. This source is located at a distance of 1.4 kpc from Earth and hosts the first pulsar to be discovered in the gamma-ray band by the gamma-ray space telescope Fermi. CTA 1 is a composite supernova remnant, with an outer shell visible at radio frequencies and an extended X-ray pulsar wind nebula surrounding the pulsar. VERITAS detected extended gamma-ray emission around the pulsar, demonstrating that the pulsar also powers a gamma-ray emitting particle wind nebula. VERITAS observations carried out in the years 2010 and 2011 allowed us to probe gamma ray emission mechanisms and particle acceleration processes in the environment of the CTA 1 pulsar wind nebulae. 

The discovery of TeV gamma-ray emission from RBS 0413, an active galaxy of the BL Lac class, by VERITAS was a significant outcome of this project. This was a joint discovery with Fermi-LAT of high energy gamma-ray emission from the blazar. BL Lac objects, like RBS 0413, are natural laboratories where particles in a jet plasma outflowing from a central supermassive black hole are accelerated to ultrarelativistic speeds. Their jets are oriented along the observer’s line of sight, resulting in extreme observational properties such as boosted apparent luminosity and minute-scale variabilities accompanying giant flares that are among nature’s most powerful energy releases. The study of RBS 0413 with VERITAS, together with multiwavelength spectral data extending from the optical band to VHE gamma rays, allowed us the opportunity to address some of the outstanding questions in blazar physics, such as the physical mechanisms that are responsible for the observed high energy emission.  

The quest for gamma-ray emission from blazars led Barnard College undergraduate Erin Kara to study two blazars behind the Galactic plane (B2013+370 and B2023+336) that were previously associated with unidentified EGRET sources. This study gave solid evidence favoring blazar counterparts for these two unidentified EGRET and Fermi sources, supporting the hypothesis that a number of unidentified gamma-ray sources at low galactic latitudes are indeed of extragalactic origin. The study also confirmed the gamma-ray band as likely the best tool to identify blazars located behind the Galactic plane, which are heavily absorbed at other wavelengths, and supported the hypothesis that a number of unidentified gamma-ray sources at low Galactic latitudes are indeed of extragalactic origin. 

The large number of TeV blazars detected to date allowed us to carry out a study of the gamma-ray observational properties of TeV-detected blazars. The synergy between the Fermi-LAT and ground-based Cherenkov telescope arrays gave us the opportunity for the first time to characterize the high-energy emission from blazars over five decades in energy, from 100 MeV to 10 TeV.
